channel.title: cata-list
channel.description: Useful lists of some of the best info, media, tools, and quotes for those who seek to understand and improve this world.

item.title: Hackers Accessed Covid Vaccine Data Through the EU Regulator
item.description: The European Medicines Agency has released limited details about the cyberattack.

item.title: CISA and FBI Warn of Rise in Ransomware Attacks Targeting K-12 Schools
item.description: The percentage of ransomware attacks against K-12 schools increased at the beginning of the 2020 school year

item.title: Hollywood Deployed Lobbyists to Win Exemptions to Strict California Lockdown
item.description: The entertainment industry has been given extensive leeway during the pandemic, even as California now faces a stay-at-home order.

item.title: Hackers Steal Pfizer/BioNTech COVID-19 Vaccine Data in Europe, Companies Say
item.description: U.S. drugmaker Pfizer and its German partner BioNTech said on Wednesday that documents related to development of their COVID-19 vaccine had been 'unlawfully accessed' in a cyberattack on Europe's medicines regulator.

item.title: Hunter Biden Tax Probe Examining Chinese Business Dealings
item.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — The Justice Department is investigating the finances of President-elect Joe Biden's son, including scrutinizing some of his Chinese business dealings and other transactions

item.title: The Hunter Biden Criminal Probe Bolsters a Chinese Scholar's Claim About Beijing's Influence With the Biden Administration
item.description: Professor Di Dongsheng says China's close ties to Wall Street and its dealings with Hunter both enable it to exert more power now than it could under Trump.

item.title: With News of Hunter Biden's Criminal Probe, Recall the Media Outlets That Peddled the 'Russian Disinformation' Lie
item.description: The now-validated facts about Hunter are precisely those the U.S. media -- in tandem with Silicon Valley and the intelligence community -- suppressed based on lies.

item.title: One Small Step for Free Speech
item.description: This week's Cambridge victory will do little to stop the march through the institutions

item.title: US Diplomats' Brain Injuries May Be From Covert Microwave Attack, Experts Say
item.description: Data from Russian experiments on pulsed RF energy offers best explanation.

item.title: Meet the Censored: Abigail Shrier
item.description: Where is the line between boycott-based activism and corporate censorship?

item.title: Pandemic Villains: Robinhood
item.description: Have a pair of gangly Stanford grads built the perfect mousetrap?

item.title: Progress Toward a Safer Psychedelic Drug to Treat Depression and Addiction
item.description: A synthetic version of the psychedelic drug ibogaine appears to relieve depression and addiction without producing hallucinations or other dangerous side effects — at least in rodents.

item.title: The Old Arctic Is Gone
item.description: Scientists have spent the past 15 years pulling together data about the Arctic into a report card. What's become clear in the 15 iterations of the report is nothing will be the same for centuries to come and the shifts are happening faster than anticipated.

item.title: Printable, Flexible Battery Offers 10 Times the Density of Lithium-Ion
item.description: Scientists investigating an experimental battery chemistry have wound up with a flexible device they say offers up to 10 times the energy density of current lithium-ion solutions, making it an ideal fit for a number of applications. The technique also allows for easier manufacturing of flexible…

item.title: Large Study of Americans Shows the Broad Health Problems Covid-19 Can Cause
item.description: New research out Tuesday looks to pin down the many health problems that can arise from a bout of covid-19. The long list includes more common ailments like pneumonia, kidney failure, and widespread inflammation, as well as rarer complications like serious heart inflammation, collapsed lungs, and se…

item.title: Biden's Choice for Pentagon Chief Further Erodes a Key U.S. Norm: Civilian Control
item.description: Gen. Lloyd Austin, on the Raytheon Board, is yet another high-level Biden nominee enmeshed in D.C.'s corporatist 'revolving door' of legalized influence-peddling.

item.title: Exclusive: U.S. Air Pollution Monitoring Network Falling Into Disrepair - GAO Report
item.description: The U.S. air pollution monitoring network has fallen into disrepair after years of budget cuts and neglect, leaving tens of millions of Americans vulnerable to undetected bad air quality from events like wildfires to industrial pollution, according to a report by the investigative...

item.title: California's Hellish 2018 Wildfires Cost the US Economy $148.5 Billion
item.description: Two years later, we're still adding unfortunate superlatives to the 2018 California wildfire season. The latest is a new study that reveals the hidden toll of what—until this year—was the state's most destructive fire season.

item.title: Exxon Holds Back on Technology That Could Slow Climate Change
item.description: Carbon capture can make money for oil giants, and scientists say we need it. Is the industry willing to invest enough?

item.title: Coca-Cola, Pepsi and Nestlé Named Top Plastic Polluters for Third Year in a Row
item.description: Companies accused of 'zero progress' on reducing plastic waste, with Coca-Cola ranked No 1 for most littered products

item.title: Quantum Device Performs 2.6 Billion Years of Computation in 4 Minutes
item.description: Photons explore quantum maze faster than possible for any classical computer.

item.title: SpaceX Gets $886 Million From FCC to Subsidize Starlink in 35 States
item.description: Charter also wins big; FCC fund will bring service to 5.2M homes and businesses.

item.title: With Guns Drawn, Police Raid Home and Seize Computers of COVID-19 Data Whistleblower
item.description: Florida fired her, and now it's raiding her home

item.title: Health Care Is Coming to Grips With Its Pollution Problem
item.description: Greenhouse gas emissions are on the rise.

item.title: The NSA Warns That Russia Is Attacking Remote Work Platforms
item.description: A vulnerability in VMWare has prompted a warning that companies—and government agencies—need to patch as soon as possible.

item.title: Black and White in the Classroom
item.description: My palms were sweating, my heart was racing, and I avoided eye contact with everyone in that room, praying hard that my teacher would not call on me. And then, 'Lola, what are your thoughts?' was said out loud. I had many thoughts and ideas I knew needed to be spoken, stories I could share to change…

item.title: Rehabilitation for Vice Bloggers
item.description: This is a new center for bloggers to get back into the normal world (comedy sketch)

item.title: Why Should the US Be Afforded the 'Power of Assassination'?
item.description: The US government's argument it has the right to assassinate anyone, anywhere heralds its descent into despotism.

item.title: Enlightenment Literature as Foreign Aid
item.description: 'If God were to humiliate a human being,' wrote Imam Ali bin abi Talib in the sixth century, 'He would deny him knowledge.' If the woeful state of knowledge in lands beset by authoritarian regimes is any indication, a great number of human beings in our world have been lavishly humiliated, albeit by…

item.title: After the Deep State Sabotaged His Presidential Bid, Bernie Sanders Mocks Those Who Believe It Exists
item.description: Also ridiculing 'rigged elections' and 'fake news' -- two other weapons used on him -- the Vermont Senator's relationship to the Democratic Party descends from loyal support to abject subservience.

item.description: The US report is the latest attempt to explain a mystery illness that affected diplomats in Cuba.

item.description: A disclosure sheds new light on a high-profile national security law as lawmakers prepare to revive a debate over it in the Biden administration.

item.title: China Is Massively Expanding Its Weather-Modification Program, Saying It Will Be Able to Cover Half the Country In artificial Rain and Snow by 2025
item.description: Beijing said Tuesday that China's 'cloud seeding' project will soon cover 2.1 million of China's 3.7 million square miles.

item.title: Overcome Stress by Visualizing It as a Greedy, Hook-Nosed Race of Creatures
item.description: On Today Now!, author Christine Eckard teaches Jim and Tracy to imagine economic problems as oily, curly-haired 'Grabblers.'

item.title: Who Will Biden Bomb First?
item.description: The President-elect's 'global leadership' is a return to neoconservatism

item.title: Student Loan Horror Stories: Borrowed: $79,000. Paid: $190,000. Now Owes? $236,000
item.description: At 59, Chris pleaded for a renegotiation. 'My life expectancy is 15 more years. At this rate, you're not going to get very much...′ Their response was, 'So?''

item.title: Congress Stalls on Stimulus Checks for Families While Corporations Continue to Reap Millions From CARES Act
item.description: The IRS is still issuing retroactive tax refunds to companies, many of which are thriving amid the coronavirus pandemic.

item.description: The setup of lasers and mirrors effectively “solved” a problem far too complicated for even the largest traditional computer system

item.title: 'This Is Not Science Fiction,' Say Scientists Pushing for 'Neuro-Rights'
item.description: Scientific advances from deep brain stimulation to wearable scanners are making manipulation of the human mind increasingly possible, creating a need for laws and protections to regulate use of the new tools, top neurologists said on Thursday.

item.title: Every Mayor, Governor Accused of Breaking COVID Restrictions — and Why
item.description: Austin Mayor Steve Adler joins a long list of leading politicians to have allegedly broken their own rules. Here's the rundown.

Peterson rose to prominence in 2016 when he posted a series of videos on YouTube denouncing a Canadian law that, he claim…

item.title: China Is National Security Threat No. 1
item.description: Resisting Beijing's attempt to reshape and dominate the world is the challenge of our generation.

item.title: Feds Claim the Patriot Act Allowed Them to Log Visitors to Websites
item.description: Letters produced by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence reportedly show that the U.S. government has interpreted Section 215 of the Patriot Act as giving it the power to monitor who visits certain websites and when, with minimal oversight.

item.title: Nation-State Backed Hackers Going After COVID Vaccine Supply Chain
item.description: Sophisticated operation is well-researched and well-placed, aimed at EU.

item.title: Doctors Release 'Most Worrying Outlook' on Climate Change and Health
item.description: The doctors are here to give the Earth its annual checkup, and they say it's running a fever which is making people sick. They issued their findings showing all the ways climate change is affecting our health in the annual Lancet Countdown on Wednesday.

item.title: The Journey of Electronic Bottles and the Ocean Plastic Crisis
item.description: Researchers loaded containers with trackers and released them in the Ganges and the Bay of Bengal, giving new insight into how plastic pollution travels.

item.title: Toxic PFAS Chemicals Discovered in Hundreds of Products
item.description: Climbing ropes, guitar strings, and hand sanitizer are among the newly reported uses for the toxic 'forever' chemicals.

item.title: The Army Tested 'Germ Warfare' on the NYC Subway by Smashing Lightbulbs Full of Bacteria
item.description: It was one of many dangerous government experiments on US citizens in violation of the Nuremberg Code.

item.title: 'One of the Largest Human Experiments in History' Was Conducted on Unsuspecting Residents of San Francisco
item.description: For 20 years, the military secretly tested biological agents on the American public.

item.title: The Heretical Impulse: Zamyatin and Orwell
item.description: I In a 1931 letter to Joseph Stalin, Russian novelist Yevgeny Zamyatin adopted a respectful tone by way of introduction: 'My name is probably known to you.' The author of We, the dystopian science fiction novel that influenced Aldous Huxley's Brave New World and George Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-Four…

item.title: Race and Social Panic at Haverford: A Case Study in Educational Dysfunction

'I came to this institution'—and here she pauses for a moment, apparently fighting back…

item.title: Elon Musk Says SpaceX Will Attempt Uncrewed Mars Flight in Two Years, Human Landing in Four to Six
item.description: SpaceX founder and CEO Elon Musk was given an award from media giant Axel Springer on Tuesday, and he sat down to provide a wide-ranging interview that covered topics including space, Tesla, AI and even underpopulation. Musk addressed SpaceX's Mars ambitions first, providing current timelines…

item.description: If you have to sneak your transformational copyright bill into a 'must pass' government spending bill, it seems fairly evident that you know the bill is bad. Earlier we talked about how the White House is trying to slip a Section 230 repeal...

item.description: The state of Iowa collects millions of dollars in fines from people whose charges were dismissed. There's also a Catch-22: financially, you're better off guilty

item.description: Iran has blamed Israel for the attack, and pledged retaliation.

item.title: Guns, Drugs and Viral Content: Welcome to Cartel TikTok

item.title: Most Americans Object to Government Tracking of Their Activities Through Cellphones
item.description: A new survey found widespread concern among Americans about government tracking of their whereabouts through their digital devices, with an overwhelming majority saying that a warrant should be required to obtain such data.

item.title: As Cities Curb Surveillance, Baltimore Police Took to the Air
item.description: In a program that overcame three court challenges this year, planes with high-tech cameras circled the city up to 40 hours a week.

item.title: Microsoft's New 'Productivity Score' Gamifies Workplace Surveillance
item.description: The company's newest feature is facing heavy criticism for allowing bosses to track how their employees use Microsoft's suite of tools, such as how frequently they send emails, collaborate in shared documents, or have their camera on during virtual meetings.

item.title: The Ethics of Rebooting the Dead
item.description: The notion of resurrecting people as digital entities is becoming less hypothetical. But just because something can be done, doesn't always mean it should.

item.description: 'I found your baby,' Michelle Durden recalls the police officer saying after her son went missing. 'He's alive. And he's in jail.'

In order to estimate this, you have…

item.title: Retracting a Controversial Paper Won't Help Female Scientists
item.description: Imagine yourself as a newly hired female assistant professor and the delight you feel when you learn that your article, examining over 222 million academic papers, has just been accepted at one of the top science journals. item.title: This Squishy 3D-Printed Human Heart Feels Like the Real Thing
item.description: A clever technique allows scientists to scan a heart and reconstruct it in a soup of gelatin. It's like making jello, only way more useful for surgeons.

item.title: Psilocybin & Migraine: First of Its Kind Trial Reports Promising Results
item.description: A first-of-its-kind exploratory study, led by researchers from Yale School of Medicine, has found a single dose of the psychedelic psilocybin can reduce migraine frequency by 50 percent for a least two weeks. The preliminary trial was small, with follow-up work necessary to validate the results,…

item.title: The Fragility of Modern Education in the Time of COVID-19
item.description: Modern education is arguably the most massive feat of social engineering ever attempted by humanity and one of the most important, when effective. Academic competencies at the end of schooling can have life-long influences on employability, wages, and the ability to advance in one's career.1,2,3,4 T…

item.title: Kin, Tribes, and the Dark Side of Identity
item.description: 'We should poison their water holes!' This was the first thing my father said when I called him after planes hit the World Trade Center where I worked. My dad was a 1960s cultural liberal and pacifist, who had opposed every war our country had fought. The moment he felt that my life was in danger, h…

item.title: Does Racism Explain Black Disadvantage?
item.description: A foundational tenet of the Black Lives Matter and similar racial justice movements is that gaps between blacks and whites on many socio-economic measures are produced primarily by racism. Racial inequalities in educational attainment, financial success, social status, crime, and health are thereby …

item.description: The police surveillance center in Jackson, Mississippi, will be conducting a 45-day pilot program to live stream the security cameras, including Amazon Ring cameras, of participating residents.

item.description: Boosted by advances in sensors and artificial intelligence, a new generation of machines is automating a tech-averse industry.

item.description: 95% less water. 99% less land. 400X more yield.
